description:
The Department of Accounting offers a Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Accounting. The accounting curriculum is designed to provide students with the conceptual, technical, and analytical competencies necessary for professional careers in accounting. Many students earning this degree elect to pursue one of the various professional accounting certifications (e.g., CPA, CMA, CIA, CISA).
The undergraduate accounting program is structured to provide students with a strong foundation in accounting principles, practices, and theories, while also developing their critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication skills. Students will gain an understanding of financial accounting, managerial accounting, auditing, taxation, and accounting information systems. The curriculum also includes courses in business law, economics, finance, and marketing, providing a well-rounded business education.
Graduates of the program are prepared for a variety of entry-level positions in public accounting firms, corporations, government agencies, and non-profit organizations. They may work as auditors, tax accountants, financial analysts, cost accountants, or internal auditors. The program also provides a solid foundation for those wishing to pursue graduate studies in accounting or business.

The Minor in Actuarial Mathematics, offered through the Department of Mathematics and Statistics, provides students with a strong theoretical and applied foundation in actuarial science and mathematical finance. Students pursuing the minor will learn to apply quantitative analytical skills to problems involving risk and uncertainty, particularly in the insurance and financial industries. Students completing the minor will be well-prepared for entry-level positions in actuarial science and mathematical finance fields, and will have completed coursework covering topics on the SOA/CAS Actuarial Exam FM (Financial Mathematics) and Actuarial Exam P (Probability).

Are you interested in a career as an actuary? This undergraduate certificate provides students with the opportunity to gain expertise in actuarial science without having to complete a full degree program. The certificate is offered primarily to students in quantitative majors like mathematics, statistics, computer science, and engineering who want to strengthen their preparation for actuarial careers. Actuaries are business professionals who deal with the financial impact of risk and uncertainty. They use mathematics, statistics, and financial theory to study uncertain future events, especially those of concern to insurance and pension programs. Actuaries design and price insurance policies, pension plans, and other financial instruments and evaluate the probability of future events. The Undergraduate Certificate in Actuarial Studies at UNC Charlotte is designed to provide students with a strong foundation in actuarial science, enhancing their competitiveness for internships and entry-level positions in the actuarial field. The curriculum covers key actuarial topics, including financial mathematics, probability, statistics, and economics, which are essential for passing the preliminary exams required for actuarial professional accreditation. The certificate also helps students prepare for professional exams by the Society of Actuaries (SOA) and the Casualty Actuarial Society (CAS). Completing the certificate demonstrates a specialized skill set and commitment to the actuarial profession, making graduates more attractive to employers in insurance companies, consulting firms, government agencies, and other organizations that manage financial risk.

The Undergraduate Certificate in Advanced Dance Studies provides a pathway for undergraduate students to gain advanced proficiency in dance technique, choreography, and performance. Students explore contemporary dance and ballet techniques, creative processes, and repertory from multiple perspectives. The certificate provides opportunities for advanced study beyond that typically offered in a minor or as electives within a major. It is especially beneficial for students who plan to pursue graduate study in dance or to work professionally in the field. The certificate is open to all undergraduate students at UNC Charlotte. Courses may count toward fulfilling general education requirements, a major or minor, or as elective credits.
Program name: Undergraduate Certificate in Advanced Dance Studies

description: The Minor in Aerospace Studies is a 15-hour minor designed for students interested in developing leadership and management skills while also exploring military history, national security, and global issues. This minor is open to all students, regardless of their major, and can complement a wide range of academic interests. The curriculum provides a foundational understanding of the U.S. Air Force and Space Force, leadership principles, and the role of air and space power in national defense. Students will engage in coursework that fosters critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication skills, preparing them for leadership roles in various fields, both civilian and military. Completion of this minor does not obligate students to join the military but offers valuable insights and skills relevant to military service.

The Africana Studies B.A. program provides students with a multidisciplinary approach to the study of African-descended peoples across Africa, North and South America, and the Caribbean. Drawing from the Humanities and Social Sciences, our coursework investigates the history, cultures, and politics of Africana peoples throughout time. Students engage with key concepts in Africana Studies, including race, racism, ethnicity, class, gender, sexuality, and nationality, through courses in history, literature, music, political science, sociology, anthropology, and religious studies. Through this rigorous program of study, students develop critical thinking, analytical, and communication skills, preparing them for a wide range of careers in education, government, social justice, nonprofit organizations, and global affairs. Our program also provides excellent preparation for graduate studies in Africana Studies, History, English, Political Science, and other related fields.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Africana Studies

description: The Health & Environment Concentration focuses on issues of health disparities, environmental racism, and environmental injustice, especially as they pertain to people of African descent. Students learn to critique conventional approaches to public health and environmental studies and explore new approaches that draw on the traditions of Africana Studies. The concentration prepares students for graduate study or careers in health, social work, public policy, environmental justice advocacy, and other related fields.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Africana Studies, Health and Environment Concentration

description: The minor in Africana Studies, housed in the Department of Africana Studies, provides students an interdisciplinary approach to the study of the peoples of African descent on the African continent and throughout the diaspora. It is designed to prepare students to understand the diverse histories, cultures, politics, and social experiences of these populations from antiquity to the present. The minor provides students the necessary intellectual tools to comprehend the origins, patterns, and consequences of global social inequalities. The program provides the intellectual framework for students to critically analyze racial formations, identity and power. A minor in Africana Studies enhances skills and knowledge that are essential in today’s diverse workforce and global society.

Concentration name: Popular Culture and Digital Media Concentration
description: This concentration in Africana Studies equips students with a critical understanding of the historical, social, political, economic, and cultural forces that shape the lives of people of African descent, particularly as these forces are shaped and expressed through popular culture and digital media. Students will examine various forms of popular culture (e.g., music, film, television, sports, fashion, gaming) and digital media (e.g., social media, online platforms, digital activism) as sites of cultural production, resistance, and identity formation within Africana communities globally. The curriculum emphasizes interdisciplinary approaches, theoretical frameworks, and research methodologies to analyze the complexities of popular culture and digital media from an Africana Studies perspective. Through this concentration, students will develop strong analytical, critical thinking, research, and communication skills, preparing them for careers in media, communications, arts and entertainment, education, public policy, community organizing, or for further graduate studies.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Africana Studies, Popular Culture and Digital Media Concentration

description: The Bachelor of Arts in Africana Studies (AFST) program is an interdisciplinary course of study that focuses on the study of people of African descent, the African continent, and the African diaspora from an historical and contemporary perspective. Drawing on a wide range of disciplines, the major provides an understanding of how race, gender, class, nationality, and sexuality shape individual and group identity and experiences. Through a critical lens, students investigate the impact of social, political, economic, and cultural forces on people of African descent. Students gain the critical thinking, communication, and research skills necessary to pursue a wide range of graduate studies and professional careers. Students can choose between four concentrations that enhance their major and lead to specific professional paths: General Concentration; Social Justice and the Law; Afro-Diasporic Languages and Global Studies; and Pre-doctoral Studies in Africana Studies.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Africana Studies, Social Justice and the Law Concentration

description: American Studies is an interdisciplinary field that examines the history, culture, and society of the United States. It encompasses a broad range of topics, including literature, history, art, music, film, religion, politics, economics, and popular culture. The field encourages students to think critically about the complexities and contradictions of American life, exploring both its unifying themes and its diverse experiences. An American Studies minor provides students with a broad understanding of American culture and society, developing their critical thinking, research, and communication skills.

The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) in Anthropology prepares students for careers in the private, public, and non-profit sectors, and for graduate studies in anthropology and related fields. Students gain an understanding of humanity in all its diversity, learning about how people live, how they organize their societies, and how they make meaning in their lives. The B.A. program provides students with practical skills in critical thinking, cross-cultural understanding, communication, and social scientific research methods. These skills are essential for addressing many of the challenges facing our increasingly interconnected and diverse world.

Anthropology is the study of humanity, in all of its diversity, in all places and at all times. Anthropologists study the origins, development, and behavior of people. They examine human societies and cultures and their development. The program focuses on three of the traditional subfields of anthropology – archaeology, cultural anthropology, and physical anthropology – providing students with an understanding of anthropology as a holistic discipline. The program offers students the opportunity to gain in-depth experience through field schools, internships, and individualized research.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Anthropology, Applied Anthropology Concentration

description: The minor in Anthropology offers students the opportunity to learn about human diversity in the past and present. Anthropology is a broad, holistic field comprised of four subfields: cultural anthropology, archaeology, biological anthropology, and linguistic anthropology. Students in the minor will gain a foundation in these different approaches to studying human societies and cultures while tailoring their coursework to their particular interests. An anthropological perspective provides students with a toolkit for understanding different cultures, navigating an increasingly globalized world, and critically analyzing social issues. It is an excellent complement to majors in the social sciences, humanities, or natural sciences.

The Bachelor of Arts in Architecture (B.A. in Architecture) is a non-professional degree for students interested in a general education with an architectural focus, rather than professional architectural licensure. Graduates may choose to pursue a graduate degree in a field related to architecture (e.g., architectural history, urban design, landscape architecture, interior architecture, industrial design, construction management, law, business) or a graduate professional degree in architecture (M.Arch). Students complete University General Education requirements, foundation courses in architectural design, history, and technology, as well as elective courses in other departments across the University. The B.A. in Architecture program typically requires four years of full-time study.

The minor in architecture is open to all students at UNC Charlotte who are interested in exploring the field of architecture. It provides an introduction to the design process and the visual language of architecture and its history. The minor is suitable for students who wish to broaden their educational experience, develop their creative capabilities, and enhance their understanding of the built environment and culture. The minor in architecture offers an introduction to the discipline to students in other fields of study at UNC Charlotte. It is a structured sequence of coursework that exposes students to the fundamental skills, concepts, and approaches within the field. The minor helps students develop visual literacy, critical thinking, and design abilities relevant to a range of professions. Whether students are curious about architecture as a potential career path, wish to gain a deeper appreciation for the built environment, or simply want to cultivate their creative problem-solving skills, the minor in architecture provides a valuable complement to their primary course of study.

A minor in Art provides students with the opportunity to pursue their interest in art outside of their major course of study. The minor requires a minimum of 18 credit hours in art courses, including foundational studies and studio electives. It offers students an opportunity to develop their understanding and skills in visual art, fostering creativity and critical thinking. The minor is a great option for students looking to complement their primary field of study with artistic expression and visual literacy.

The Bachelor of Fine Arts (B.F.A.) is a professional studio degree designed for students who intend to pursue graduate study in the visual arts, or who wish to work as professional artists. The B.F.A. requires the demonstration of advanced studio practice and the completion of a Senior Project during the final year of study. Areas of Concentration within the B.F.A. program include: Art Education, Art History, Crafts, Digital Media, Drawing, Painting, Photography, Printmaking, and 3D Interdisciplinary Studies.
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Art, 3D Interdisciplinary Studies Concentration
Bachelor of Arts in Art, Art History Concentration

description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts (B.F.A.) in Art is a professional degree in studio art or art education. The program enables students to develop their creative and intellectual abilities as artists, designers, educators, or scholars. Students choose a concentration in one of ten areas. The B.F.A. in Art provides a professional degree option for students who wish to pursue a career in the visual arts. The B.F.A. requires 81 credit hours in the major compared to 54 for the B.A. in Art. The additional 27 hours provide students with a depth of study and studio experiences rarely found in undergraduate programs. The studio art concentrations are Ceramics, Digital Art, Fibers, Illustration, Painting, Photography, Print Media, and Sculpture. The B.F.A. in Art with a concentration in Art Education (K-12) prepares students for initial licensure as art teachers in North Carolina public schools. The B.F.A. in Art History provides a more intensive study of the history of art. All B.F.A. students are required to complete a capstone experience, which includes a professional exhibition (studio art concentrations) or a senior thesis/portfolio (Art History and Art Education concentrations).
Accreditation status: The College of Arts + Architecture is an accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Art and Design (NASAD).
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Art, Ceramics Concentration

description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) degree is a professional degree providing in-depth study in a chosen concentration. The program demands high academic achievement and exceptional creative and productive abilities. Students pursuing the BFA degree are preparing for careers as practicing professional artists, for graduate study, and for a variety of occupations that require advanced creative and critical thinking skills. They develop a thorough understanding of their discipline by focusing on conceptual, formal, and technical development. Students are encouraged to develop a personal aesthetic in their studio work and to engage in critical discourse about art and culture. Upon completion of the BFA, students will have a substantial portfolio of original works of art developed from their concentration.
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Art, Digital Media Concentration

description: The Fibers concentration develops studio skills in textile processes that include weaving, surface design, dyeing, papermaking, stitching, and fiber sculpture. Students learn to think critically and conceptually through studio assignments, historical research, and professional practices in a contemporary art context. Students are encouraged to develop an individual and professional voice, grounded in the investigation of historical and contemporary applications of art in fiber.
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Art, Fibers Concentration

description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts (B.F.A.) in Art is a professional degree program for students seeking careers as practicing artists and designers, or pursuing further study in graduate school. The B.F.A. is a highly competitive and selective program within the Department of Art and Art History, requiring significant academic achievement for admission. It emphasizes advanced studio experience in one of 11 concentrations.
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Art, Graphic Design Concentration

description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts (B.F.A.) in Art offers concentrations in Ceramics, Digital Art, Fibers, Illustration, Painting, Photography, Print Media, and Sculpture. The B.F.A. program is a pre-professional degree for students preparing for graduate study in art or seeking careers as professional artists, designers, or illustrators.
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Art, Illustration Concentration

description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts (B.F.A.) in Art program with a concentration in Painting is a professional degree providing in-depth study in studio art. This program prepares students for a career as a practicing artist or for further study at the graduate level. Students will develop a professional portfolio and hone their skills in various painting techniques, color theory, composition, and conceptual development. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, historical context, and contemporary art practices within the discipline of painting. Through rigorous studio work, critiques, and exhibitions, students will cultivate their individual artistic voice and prepare for entry into the professional art world.
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Art, Painting Concentration

description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) degree is a professional degree in studio art that leads to a variety of careers in the visual arts, including studio practice, art education, and arts administration. Students may concentrate in one of the following areas: Art Education, Ceramics, Digital Arts, Drawing, Fibers, Graphic Design, Illustration, Painting, Photography, Printmaking, Sculpture.
Accreditation status: Accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Art and Design (NASAD)
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Art, Photography Concentration

description: The Print Media Area provides students with an understanding of traditional printmaking processes, digital applications and the history of print media as a creative outlet. Our facilities include intaglio, lithography, relief, serigraphy and darkroom photography. We are committed to exposing students to the expansive possibilities of print media, including the mixing of both traditional and digital processes. Printmaking encourages students to develop a strong image-making aesthetic, conceptual clarity, and critical thinking skills across a variety of media.
Accreditation status: The Department of Art & Art History at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte is an accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Art and Design (NASAD).
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Art, Print Media Concentration

description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) degree in Art is a professional degree that prepares students for careers as practicing artists and designers. Students must apply for admission to the BFA program during their sophomore year and are accepted into one of the nine concentrations in their junior year. The BFA requires 120 credit hours and culminates in a professional exhibition or portfolio review. The BFA Art History concentration prepares students for graduate study in art history or related fields.
Accreditation status: The Department of Art & Art History is an accredited member of the National Association of Schools of Art and Design (NASAD).
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Art, Sculpture Concentration

description: The Minor in Asian Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive background in the languages, cultures, histories, and religions of Asia. The minor is flexible, allowing students to tailor the program to their individual interests by selecting courses from a variety of departments and colleges. The Asian Studies minor allows students to pursue their interests in Asian cultures while completing their major in another field. The Minor in Asian Studies complements a variety of majors, including History, Political Science, International Studies, Religious Studies, Languages, Communication, and Business, among others. Students who earn a Minor in Asian Studies will gain valuable knowledge and understanding of Asian cultures, which can be beneficial for careers in government, business, education, journalism, and non-profit organizations, as well as for further graduate study.

A minor in Astronomy at UNC Charlotte provides students with a foundational understanding of the universe, covering topics from the solar system to distant galaxies and cosmology. Students will explore celestial mechanics, astrophysics, and observational astronomy through a combination of coursework and hands-on experiences. This minor complements a wide range of majors, including Physics, Engineering, Computer Science, and Education, enhancing career prospects in fields requiring analytical skills and a scientific mindset. The program aims to foster critical thinking and problem-solving abilities within the context of astronomical phenomena. Graduates will be prepared to contribute to scientific research, engage in science communication, or pursue further studies in astronomy and related sciences.

The Bachelor of Science in Biology provides students with a broad and rigorous foundation in the biological sciences. Through a combination of coursework, laboratory experiences, and research opportunities, students develop critical thinking skills, scientific literacy, and a deep understanding of biological principles. The curriculum is designed to prepare students for diverse career paths in research, healthcare, biotechnology, environmental science, and education, as well as for advanced studies in graduate or professional programs.

The Department of Biological Sciences offers a minor in Biology to students who are not majoring in Biology. The minor requires a minimum of 18 credit hours and provides an overview of the field and its core concepts. This minor is designed for students who wish to gain a basic understanding of biology without committing to a full major. It is a good complement for majors in fields such as Public Health, Psychology, Sociology, and other related disciplines, as biological principles are increasingly important across a wide range of fields.

The minor in Biotechnology offers students the opportunity to learn about the theory and application of modern biotechnology. The minor is offered to students from any major, but is most easily acquired by students majoring in the life or physical sciences and engineering. The minor provides foundational knowledge and hands-on skills to prepare students for careers in biotechnology or further study in advanced degree programs.

This minor is a general business minor for students in non-business majors. It provides an overview of various aspects of business for students who may interact with business organizations in their future careers. Students completing the minor will also be prepared to pursue graduate study in business. Admission and Completion Requirements: * A minimum of 2.0 institutional GPA and 2.0 major GPA * A minimum of C in all courses applied to the minor (excludes transfer credit) * At least 9 hours of coursework must be taken at UNC Charlotte * At least 6 hours of upper-level coursework must be taken at UNC Charlotte * Students must complete 18 credit hours, as outlined in the catalog, with a grade of C or better in each course. * Only courses with the prefix ACC, BANA, FINN, LBST, MGMT, MKTG, REAL, and SCMG are acceptable to the Belk College of Business. * Please consult the department for additional information.

The Business Analytics concentration provides students with the knowledge and skills necessary to apply data-driven approaches to solve business problems. Students learn how to collect, analyze, and interpret large datasets, as well as how to communicate their findings effectively to stakeholders. The curriculum emphasizes both technical skills (e.g., statistical modeling, data mining, visualization) and business acumen, preparing graduates for roles in various industries where data plays a crucial role in decision-making.
Accreditation status: Accredited by AACSB International
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Business Administration, Business Analytics Concentration

description: The Bachelor of Science in Chemistry (B.S. in Chemistry) provides a strong foundation in all areas of chemistry and prepares students for a wide variety of career options and advanced study. The program provides a flexible curriculum, with opportunities to specialize in a variety of sub-disciplines (biochemistry, environmental chemistry, forensic chemistry, materials chemistry, nanoscale chemistry, pre-health professions, professional chemistry, or chemistry education) or to obtain a broad background in chemistry. Our graduates are well-prepared for entry into graduate school (M.S. or Ph.D.), professional school (medical, dental, pharmacy, optometry, or veterinary), high school teaching (science licensure), or employment in industry or government.

The minor in Chemistry is available to students who desire to broaden their knowledge in Chemistry. The Minor provides students with fundamental knowledge in the principal areas of Chemistry: Analytical, Biochemistry, Inorganic, Organic, and Physical. Students who take the Minor in Chemistry will obtain hands-on training with modern laboratory instrumentation. The Minor in Chemistry will also help students develop quantitative skills, critical thinking, problem-solving skills, and written and oral communication skills.

The Chinese minor is offered through the Department of Languages and Culture Studies. It is open to all students, regardless of major. Students pursuing a Chinese minor are encouraged to participate in a study abroad program in China. The University offers a variety of study abroad programs, including summer, semester, and year-long programs. Students may also consult the Department of Languages and Culture Studies regarding transfer credit from other study abroad programs. All requests for transfer credit must be approved in advance by the Department of Languages and Culture Studies. Charlotte is the second largest banking center in the United States and home to a growing number of international businesses. With China’s increasing economic and political importance in the world, the knowledge of Chinese language and culture is in high demand in the American workplace and marketplace. The Chinese minor provides students with a competitive edge in seeking careers in business, communication, engineering, government, health and human services, and other fields that engage globally with the Chinese-speaking world. In addition, the Chinese minor helps prepare students for graduate studies related to Chinese language, literature, and culture.

Civil engineering is a professional engineering discipline that deals with the design, construction, and maintenance of the physical and naturally built environment, including works like roads, bridges, canals, dams, and buildings. Civil engineering is the oldest engineering discipline after military engineering, and it was defined to distinguish non-military engineering from military engineering. It is traditionally broken into several sub-disciplines including environmental engineering, geotechnical engineering, structural engineering, transportation engineering, municipal or urban engineering, water resources engineering, materials engineering, coastal engineering, surveying, and construction engineering. Civil engineers design, construct, and maintain infrastructure projects and systems in the public and private sectors, including roads, bridges, canals, dams, airports, sewerage systems, pipelines, structural components of buildings, and railways.
Accreditation status: The Civil Engineering undergraduate program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Civil Engineering

description: The minor in Civil Engineering is designed for students seeking to broaden their knowledge in the field of Civil Engineering or complement their undergraduate major. The minor allows students to take courses in several Civil Engineering sub-disciplines including construction, environmental, geotechnical, structural, transportation, and water resources engineering. Students will gain knowledge of the principles of planning, design, construction, and maintenance of the built and natural environments.

The Minor in Classical Studies will provide students with the opportunity to study the languages, literature, history, and culture of ancient Greece and Rome. Students will select courses from a range of offerings in Classical Greek, Latin, ancient history, archaeology, classical mythology, and related fields. The minor encourages students to gain an understanding of the impact of the Greco-Roman world on the arts, sciences, and Western thought. A minor in Classical Studies complements a wide variety of majors, including Anthropology, Art History, English, History, International Studies, Philosophy, Political Science, Religious Studies, and Modern Languages.

A minor in Communication Studies requires a minimum of 18 credit hours and offers students the opportunity to learn how to analyze communication situations, develop effective strategies, and apply those strategies in a variety of contexts.

A Bachelor of Arts degree in Communication Studies provides an understanding of how communication functions in various social, cultural, and professional contexts. Students learn to think critically about human communication processes and their effects, develop skills to become more effective communicators, and apply communication theories to analyze and solve problems. This degree prepares students to enter a variety of professional fields or to pursue graduate studies in Communication or related disciplines. Students earning a B.A. in Communication Studies choose from two concentrations: Health Communication or Public Relations. All Communication Studies students take a set of core courses and then additional coursework that applies to their chosen concentration. The Health Communication Concentration focuses on the study of human communication in health and illness contexts. The courses provide students with an understanding of: Effective health messaging across diverse populations, Provider-patient communication, Health campaigns and interventions, Cultural influences on health communication, Media portrayals of health.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Communication Studies, Health Communication Concentration

description: Communication Studies is a dynamic and thriving discipline that focuses on how people create, transmit, interpret, and are influenced by messages. Communication Studies draws from both the humanities and social sciences and offers students skills in critical thinking, research, problem solving, oral and written communication, leadership, and intercultural competence. Communication Studies majors find careers in business, government, law, education, health, public relations, human resources, non-profits, mass media, and more. Our graduates are in demand and prepared to make a difference in their communities and professions. They also pursue graduate study in a range of fields, including communication, law, business, and health. The Mass Media Concentration is for students who want to develop skills in critical analysis, research, ethics, and practices in advertising, journalism, public relations, and other related mass media industries. Students prepare for a wide range of careers in mass media, public relations, human resources, business, government, and related fields. This concentration also provides excellent preparation for graduate study in communication, law, and other related fields.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Communication Studies, Mass Media Concentration

description: The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) in Communication Studies prepares students for careers in fields such as business, education, government, and law. Communication Studies focuses on human interaction and the symbolic processes that create meaning in social, cultural, and political contexts. Students develop skills in critical thinking, research, problem-solving, and oral and written communication. The Communication Studies major offers three concentrations: Health Communication, Organizational Communication, and Public Advocacy. The Organizational Communication concentration focuses on communication within and between organizations. Students explore topics such as leadership, team building, conflict management, organizational culture, and strategic communication. This concentration prepares students for careers in human resources, public relations, internal communication, and management.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Communication Studies, Organizational Communication Concentration

description: The Public Advocacy concentration focuses on the study of communication within various contexts related to social and political issues, public policy, and justice. This concentration provides students with the theoretical and practical tools to analyze, craft, and deliver persuasive messages, engage in public debate, and advocate for causes and communities. Students learn about argumentation, rhetoric, campaign strategies, and ethical considerations in public discourse. This concentration prepares students for careers in law, government, non-profit organizations, political campaigns, public relations, and community organizing.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Communication Studies, Public Advocacy Concentration

description: The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Communication Studies program helps students develop the knowledge and skills necessary for effective communication in a variety of contexts and careers. The program’s curriculum provides a broad understanding of communication theories and research, as well as opportunities for students to apply their knowledge in practical settings. In this program, students develop strong critical thinking, analytical, and problem-solving skills, and become adept at crafting compelling messages for diverse audiences. Graduates are well-prepared for a wide range of careers in fields such as public relations, marketing, human resources, journalism, media, education, and government, as well as for graduate study in communication or related disciplines. The Public Relations concentration specifically involves managing communication between organizations and their publics. Students learn to research, plan, implement, and evaluate communication strategies for clients in corporate, government, and non-profit settings.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Communication Studies, Public Relations Concentration

description: The Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering offers a Bachelor of Science (BS) degree in Computer Engineering. The program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET. Computer engineering is a discipline that integrates several fields of electrical engineering and computer science required to develop computer hardware and software. Computer engineers are involved in many aspects of computing, from the design of individual microcontrollers, microprocessors, personal computers, and supercomputers, to circuit design. This field of engineering not only focuses on how computer systems themselves work, but also how they integrate into the larger picture. Students will gain a broad background in computer engineering including computer architecture, digital systems, embedded systems, very large scale integrated (VLSI) circuit design, computer networking, and cybersecurity. Students are prepared for immediate employment in areas such as integrated circuit design, electronic design automation (EDA), embedded systems design, computer architecture, network system design, information technology, and cybersecurity. The program also prepares students for graduate studies in computer engineering, electrical engineering, and computer science.
Accreditation status: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Computer Engineering

description: Computer engineering is an essential field with a diverse range of applications, including computer vision, embedded systems, robotics, wireless communication, and many others. This minor will provide students with the foundational knowledge of computer engineering and its applications across multiple industries and disciplines. Students will explore topics such as circuit theory, microcontrollers, embedded systems, and more. This minor is intended for students who want to develop a deeper understanding of computer engineering and enhance their knowledge of computer hardware and software. It's a great choice for students majoring in Computer Science, Electrical Engineering, or other STEM fields who want to broaden their expertise.

Our Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Computer Science is a less mathematically intensive program than the Bachelor of Science (BS) in Computer Science, and it is a good option for students who wish to combine their interest in computing with other interests, for example, in the arts, humanities, business, or other sciences. Our BA program is designed for those seeking a broad background in computing complemented by significant coursework in another discipline. The BA also helps students to meet the demand in industry for computer professionals with strong communication and interdisciplinary skills. The BA in Computer Science requires 120 credit hours.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Computer Science

description: Computer science is the study of theory, experimentation, and engineering that forms the basis for the design and use of computers. Computer scientists are involved in all aspects of computing, from the design of individual microprocessors, personal computers and supercomputers, to the design of operating systems and application software, to the creation of entire networks. Computer scientists develop and design software, solve computing problems, and develop new ways to use computers. The Bachelor of Science in Computer Science provides students with the fundamental knowledge and problem-solving skills to embark on careers as computing professionals, or to pursue graduate studies in computer science. Students in the Computer Science program choose from one of six concentrations: Artificial Intelligence, Cybersecurity, Data Science, Software Engineering, Web and Mobile Applications, and Computer Science (General).
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science

description: Students minoring in Computer Science will learn about topics such as algorithms, data structures, programming languages, software engineering, databases, and computer systems. The Computer Science minor is suitable for students who wish to supplement their major with fundamental computing knowledge and skills. It is not suitable for students who wish to pursue graduate studies in computer science. Students interested in pursuing graduate studies in computer science should consider the Computer Science Post-Baccalaureate Certificate.

The Bachelor of Science in Construction Management program at UNC Charlotte prepares students for professional careers in the construction industry. Construction is a diverse global industry, encompassing many types of construction projects, including residential, commercial, industrial, and heavy civil. Students in the Construction Management program learn about the business practices, technical knowledge, and critical management skills necessary to plan, organize, and manage the complete construction process. The program also provides knowledge in the application of current construction management technology and sustainability practices. The BS in Construction Management is a STEM-designated degree. The program provides the foundational knowledge and technical skills to manage the construction process. It integrates business with construction engineering and building science. The curriculum includes courses in construction methods and materials, estimating, scheduling, project management, contracts, safety, surveying, structural systems, mechanical and electrical systems, and sustainable construction practices.
Accreditation status: Accredited by the American Council for Construction Education (ACCE)
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Construction Management

description: The Minor in Criminal Justice and Criminology provides students with a foundational understanding of the criminal justice system, crime, and related social issues. This interdisciplinary minor explores topics such as law enforcement, courts, corrections, victimology, and theories of crime causation. Students will develop critical thinking skills, research abilities, and an awareness of policy debates within the field. The minor is suitable for students pursuing a variety of majors who wish to enhance their understanding of crime and justice in society.
Program name: Minor in Criminal Justice and Criminology

description: Dance is an art form rooted in human expression with the power to communicate ideas, tell stories, and transcend linguistic and cultural barriers. The Bachelor of Arts in Dance provides a comprehensive, conservatory-style program for students with an interest in dance as a liberal art and a commitment to rigorous training and critical thought. The program provides the knowledge, skills, and experiences that prepare students for careers in dance performance, choreography, pedagogy, and scholarship. In addition, students gain competencies that are highly valued in any profession: creativity, critical thinking, problem solving, communication, collaboration, cross-cultural understanding, and self-awareness.
Accreditation status: The Department of Dance is an accredited institutional member of the National Association of Schools of Dance (NASD).

description: The Department of Dance Minor allows students who are not Dance Majors or Dance Liberal Arts Majors to pursue an academic course of study in dance. The Minor may be useful to students pursuing degrees in areas such as Music, Theatre, Education, Health and Physical Education, Psychology, Communications, or other areas for which dance training and experience might be beneficial.

The Bachelor of Science in Data Science is a highly interdisciplinary program designed to prepare students for careers in the rapidly growing field of data science. Data Science involves extracting knowledge and insights from data through a scientific approach. Students in this program will learn to collect, clean, analyze, interpret, and visualize complex datasets, applying a combination of statistical, computational, and domain-specific expertise. The curriculum covers foundational topics in mathematics, statistics, and computer science, alongside specialized courses in machine learning, data mining, big data technologies, and ethical considerations in data science. Graduates will be equipped with the analytical skills and practical experience necessary to solve real-world data challenges across various industries, including healthcare, finance, technology, and research.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Data Science

description: The Data Science Minor provides students with an interdisciplinary understanding of data science principles and practices, combining knowledge and skills from computer science, mathematics, statistics, and domain-specific areas. The curriculum emphasizes data collection, cleaning, analysis, visualization, and interpretation, as well as the ethical considerations inherent in working with data. Students will develop foundational skills in programming, statistical modeling, machine learning, and data management, preparing them for a wide range of data-centric careers or further study in data science or related fields.

Concentration name: Applied Economic Analysis, Business Analytics, Environmental and Energy Economics, Quantitative Economics
description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Economics degree provides students with a strong foundation in economic theory, methods, and applications. The curriculum emphasizes analytical and quantitative skills that prepare students for a wide range of careers in both the private and public sectors, as well as for graduate study in economics or related fields. Students gain a deep understanding of economic principles, data analysis techniques, and policy implications, enabling them to make informed decisions and contribute to economic solutions in a complex global environment. The program offers several concentrations allowing students to specialize in areas such as Applied Economic Analysis, Business Analytics, Environmental and Energy Economics, or Quantitative Economics.

The Minor in Economics is available to all students not majoring in economics. This minor requires 18 credit hours beyond ECON 1101 and 1102. The minor provides a more extensive understanding of economics than is obtained through the General Education courses without the additional mathematics and business courses required in the Economics B.S. and B.A. Programs.

Electrical engineering is a broad discipline that focuses on the study, design, and application of systems and devices that use electricity, electronics, and electromagnetism. Electrical engineers are at the forefront of technological advancements, creating innovations that power our world, connect our communities, and drive progress in countless industries. From developing advanced power systems and renewable energy solutions to designing intricate communication networks, microelectronic devices, and control systems, electrical engineers play a pivotal role in shaping the modern technological landscape. The Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering (B.S.E.E.) program at UNC Charlotte provides students with a strong theoretical foundation and practical skills necessary to excel in this dynamic field. Our curriculum covers a wide range of topics, including circuits, electronics, electromagnetics, digital systems, power systems, control systems, and communication systems. Students gain hands-on experience through laboratory work, design projects, and opportunities for undergraduate research. Graduates of the B.S.E.E. program are well-prepared for diverse career paths in industries such as energy, telecommunications, aerospace, defense, automotive, healthcare, and consumer electronics, as well as for further graduate studies.
Accreditation status: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering

description: The Electrical Engineering minor is intended for students who wish to gain additional knowledge and understanding in the fundamentals of electrical engineering principles and practices. Students will acquire a breadth of knowledge in various electrical engineering sub-disciplines including circuit analysis, electronics, digital systems, microcontrollers, electromagnetics, and signal processing. The minor provides a technical background for students in other engineering and science fields as well as those interested in careers involving electrical systems.

The Bachelor of Arts in Elementary Education prepares students to teach in grades K-6. Graduates of the program are eligible for North Carolina Class A Professional Educator licensure. The program provides a comprehensive understanding of elementary education through coursework and field experiences. Students develop skills in curriculum development, instructional strategies, assessment, and classroom management. The program emphasizes culturally responsive teaching practices and the integration of technology in the classroom. Upon completion, students are prepared to create engaging and supportive learning environments for all children.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Elementary Education

description: English majors at UNC Charlotte explore literature, writing, and language in all its forms. Our students delve into the history of literature, hone their skills in creative and professional writing, and examine language from a critical perspective. Our program provides a solid grounding in analytical thinking, research, and communication skills applicable to a wide array of professional fields or graduate study. The English curriculum includes a variety of courses within a flexible degree program where students can customize their course of study and choose from five concentrations: Creative Writing; Language and Digital Humanities; Literature, Culture, and Critical Theory; Professional Writing and Rhetoric; and Teacher Licensure (Secondary English Education). Students can also pursue a second major in another discipline without adding significant time to their studies. The Department of English also offers the Master of Arts in English, the Master of Fine Arts in Creative Writing, and the Ph.D. in English.

The Minor in English helps students develop skills in critical reading, analysis, argumentation, and written and oral communication relevant to a wide range of career fields. Students choose from a variety of courses emphasizing literature, writing, linguistics, and cultural studies.

Environmental engineering is the application of scientific and engineering principles to improve the natural environment (air, water, and land resources), to provide healthy water, air, and land, and to cleanup pollution sites. UNC Charlotte’s Environmental Engineering program provides students with the foundational knowledge and problem-solving skills necessary to address complex environmental problems. This program emphasizes sustainable approaches to environmental protection and resource management, focusing on key areas such as water and wastewater treatment, air pollution control, solid and hazardous waste management, and environmental impact assessment. Graduates are prepared for careers in consulting, government agencies, and industry, or for further graduate studies.
Accreditation status: Our undergraduate programs in Civil Engineering and Environmental Engineering are accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Environmental Engineering

description: The Environmental Engineering Minor offers students the opportunity to learn about important environmental issues and how to apply engineering principles to develop solutions. It introduces students to relevant engineering topics such as water and wastewater treatment, air quality management, hazardous waste, and sustainability. The Minor in Environmental Engineering is beneficial for students in the areas of civil, mechanical, chemical, biological systems, and earth sciences who wish to broaden their knowledge in environmental engineering areas relevant to their primary major.

The Minor in Environmental Science is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a fundamental understanding of environmental issues in the context of their chosen major. The minor complements a student’s major by providing them with an understanding of how environmental factors relate to and affect their discipline. Students learn about the scientific principles related to environmental issues and develop critical thinking skills necessary for evaluating environmental problems and solutions from a scientific perspective. The minor provides a strong scientific foundation and analytical skills that are useful for understanding and addressing the complex environmental challenges facing society. Through a combination of coursework and practical experiences, students develop the skills and knowledge to address environmental issues in a variety of settings.

The minor in Ethics and Applied Philosophy is intended for students who want to develop practical ethical reasoning skills. These skills are extremely valuable in many fields, including business, healthcare, education, law, journalism, public service, and science and technology. The minor is also relevant for students pursuing a major in Philosophy or Religious Studies, or a minor in Religious Studies. The curriculum offers an interdisciplinary approach to ethics in a variety of contexts, allowing students to explore issues related to personal and professional ethics, as well as moral questions concerning social justice, the environment, emerging technologies, and global challenges. By examining different ethical frameworks and their application to real-world problems, students will enhance their critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication abilities. The minor emphasizes the practical application of ethical principles, preparing students to navigate complex moral dilemmas and contribute to positive change in their chosen careers and communities. Students will gain a deeper understanding of ethical theories and their relevance in contemporary society. They will learn to identify and analyze ethical issues, evaluate different moral perspectives, and formulate reasoned arguments. Through case studies, discussions, and projects, students will develop the capacity to apply ethical reasoning to a wide range of situations, fostering intellectual growth and personal development. Upon completion of the minor, students will be equipped with a robust ethical toolkit, enabling them to make informed decisions, advocate for ethical practices, and address the moral dimensions of pressing societal challenges.
Program name: Minor in Ethics and Applied Philosophy

description: The European Studies Minor allows students to develop an interdisciplinary background in the histories, languages, cultures, and political and economic systems of Europe. Students will be exposed to a wide variety of courses that address the historical development of Europe, its contemporary importance in the globalized world, and its many rich cultural traditions. The minor is a useful complement for students in a wide variety of majors, including Anthropology, Art History, Communication, History, International Studies, Languages, Philosophy, Political Science, Religious Studies, and Sociology. It can also provide a solid foundation for students interested in careers in government, journalism, international business, and graduate studies.

The Bachelor of Science in Exercise Science program prepares students to work in various health and wellness settings, including corporate wellness, community health, cardiac rehabilitation, and strength and conditioning. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in human anatomy and physiology, biomechanics, exercise physiology, and exercise testing and prescription. Students also gain practical experience through internships and research opportunities. Graduates of the program are well-prepared for entry-level positions in the exercise science field or for further graduate study in areas such as physical therapy, occupational therapy, and chiropractic. Upon completion of the Bachelor of Science in Exercise Science program, students will be able to: Describe the anatomical, physiological, and biomechanical responses and adaptations to exercise. Conduct various fitness assessments and interpret the results. Design and implement safe and effective exercise programs for diverse populations. Understand the ethical and professional responsibilities in the field of exercise science. Communicate effectively both orally and in writing regarding exercise science concepts.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Exercise Science

description: The Bachelor of Science in Finance provides students with a strong theoretical and practical foundation in financial management, investments, and financial markets and institutions. The program is designed to develop problem-solving and decision-making skills required for success in a diverse and dynamic financial environment. Students will gain an understanding of financial principles, analytical tools, and ethical considerations relevant to various finance careers. Through a comprehensive curriculum, students learn to analyze financial data, evaluate investment opportunities, manage financial risk, and make informed financial decisions in both corporate and personal contexts.

The Finance Minor is designed for students outside of the Belk College of Business who wish to expand their knowledge of financial concepts. The minor consists of 15 credit hours requiring a minimum grade of C in each course. Students must complete FINN 2120 and FINN 3120 plus 9 credit hours of 3000-4000 level Finance courses. A minimum cumulative GPA of 2.5 is required in all courses counting toward the minor. Admission to the minor requires a cumulative GPA of 2.5 overall, a C or better in ACCT 2121 and MATH 1120 or MATH 1241 or MATH 1242 or MATH 1340 or MATH 1342. Students should consult the Belk College of Business academic advisor for minor admission requirements. The Minor in Finance does not have any concentrations.

Program name: Minor in Fire and Emergency Management

description: The Foreign Language Education minor prepares students to teach a foreign language (American Sign Language, Arabic, Chinese, French, German, Japanese, Latin, or Spanish) in grades K-12. This program of study is offered through the Department of Languages and Culture Studies in the College of Liberal Arts & Sciences and the Department of Middle, Secondary, and K-12 Education in the Cato College of Education. Upon successful completion of the minor requirements, students are eligible for a K-12 teaching license in a foreign language. Teacher licensure candidates must apply to and be admitted to the Cato College of Education's Teacher Education Program, satisfy all requirements for admission, complete all required courses with a C or better, and pass the required state licensure exams. Teacher licensure can only be completed by students also completing a related bachelor’s degree in the target language (e.g., a French major completing the Foreign Language Education minor to be eligible for a K-12 French teaching license).

A minor in French is an excellent complement to any major for students interested in developing knowledge of French language and culture. Students completing the minor develop proficiency in speaking, understanding, reading, and writing in French, as well as an understanding of the diverse cultures of the French-speaking world. A minor in French will broaden a student’s career opportunities in areas such as education, international business, communications, and public service.

The minor in Geography requires 18 credit hours, 9 of which must be at the 3000-level or above. Students must choose an advising concentration, either Human Geography, Physical Geography, or Geographic Information Science. At least 6 credits of GEOG coursework must be taken at UNC Charlotte. A maximum of 6 credits from transfer coursework may be applied to the minor. A minimum GPA of 2.0 in the minor is required. For more information, please see the Academic Catalog.

The Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences offers a minor in Geology. This minor provides students with a fundamental understanding of Earth processes, materials, and history. Students will develop skills in geological observation, analysis, and interpretation, which are valuable in various fields, including environmental science, natural resource management, and urban planning. The curriculum covers core geological concepts, including mineralogy, petrology, structural geology, stratigraphy, and paleontology.

The German Minor is offered by the Department of Languages and Culture Studies. A minor in German is designed for students interested in developing their proficiency in the German language and gaining a deeper understanding of German culture and society. Students will explore German literature, history, and contemporary issues, enhancing their global perspective and intercultural communication skills. This minor complements a wide range of majors, including International Business, History, Political Science, and Engineering, providing valuable language and cultural competencies for careers in various fields.

The Gerontology Minor offers students an opportunity to study human aging. The minor is interdisciplinary and examines aging from the perspectives of sociology, psychology, public health, nursing, biology, and other fields. The minor provides a foundation for students who plan to pursue careers working with older adults, who are interested in conducting research on aging, or who are interested in further graduate study in gerontology. A minor in Gerontology provides students with the opportunity to specialize in an area of study that prepares them to address the challenges facing older adults and their families.

The Minor in Global Studies provides students with the opportunity to gain expertise in global issues and a deeper understanding of the processes of globalization. The curriculum is designed to provide students with an interdisciplinary understanding of topics such as international political economy, global development, global health, global conflict, international environmental studies, and transnational cultural movements. The minor encourages students to critically examine their own societies and cultures in relation to others, to develop an appreciation for human diversity, and to cultivate the skills necessary for responsible global citizenship.

The Bachelor of Arts in Health Communication is an interdisciplinary program designed to provide students with foundational knowledge of communication and health contexts as well as practical experience in both fields. Graduates will be equipped with critical skills in research, analysis, and communication that are necessary for effectively navigating the complexities of healthcare.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Health Communication

description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) in Health Systems Management is offered by the Department of Public Health Sciences. The program is designed to develop students into ethical, effective and transformational leaders, managers, and problem solvers in a variety of health care organizations and agencies. The program prepares students to meet current and future challenges in the changing healthcare environment. A student graduating from this program will acquire knowledge and skills to manage, evaluate, and provide leadership to a range of health care organizations including hospitals, health care systems, managed care organizations, health insurance companies, pharmaceutical companies, long-term care facilities, consulting firms, government health agencies, and health information technology firms. Graduates are prepared for entry-level managerial positions and graduate study.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Health Systems Management

description: The Minor in Health Systems Management focuses on providing foundational business, organizational, and technical knowledge for students interested in careers in the growing health care industry. The minor is a collaborative effort between the Belk College of Business and the College of Health and Human Services, and is open to students in any major, especially those pursuing majors in other health care-related fields or business majors interested in the health care industry. The minor also may be of interest to pre-health students to gain a better understanding of how health care organizations are managed.

The Bachelor of Arts in History provides students with a broad and deep understanding of human experience in the past. It offers both chronological and geographical breadth, ensuring that students are exposed to a range of historical periods and regions. Students develop critical thinking skills, research abilities, and clear communication—written and oral—that are highly valued in diverse professional fields and graduate programs. Graduates with a B.A. in History pursue careers in education, law, public service, journalism, business, archival management, and museum studies, among others.

A minor in History consists of 18 credit hours, 6 of which must be at the 3000-level or above. Students must receive a grade of “C” or better in all courses taken for the minor. No more than 6 credit hours of transfer credit may be applied to the minor. The minor in History can be a valuable complement to majors across the university, offering students a broader perspective on the issues and questions they are studying in their chosen field. The flexibility of the minor also allows students to focus on areas of particular interest to them (for example, American history, European history, or global history), or to explore a broad range of historical periods and regions. A minor in History helps students hone the analytical, research, and writing skills that are applicable to a wide variety of career paths.

The Minor in Holocaust, Genocide, and Human Rights Studies provides students with a multidisciplinary understanding of the origins, dynamics, and legacies of the Holocaust and other genocides, as well as the history, theory, and practice of human rights. The minor fosters critical thinking about social, political, and historical processes leading to human rights violations and mass violence, and how such atrocities can be prevented. Students will gain knowledge of specific historical case studies as well as theoretical tools to analyze past and present patterns of human rights violations. Students will engage with historical, political, ethical, and legal aspects of the Holocaust, genocide, and human rights through different disciplinary lenses. The minor is a valuable complement to a variety of majors including Political Science, History, Religious Studies, Communication, Criminal Justice, English, International Studies, Philosophy, Social Work, and Sociology.
Program name: Minor in Holocaust, Genocide, and Human Rights Studies

description: The minor in Industrial and Systems Engineering is for students seeking to gain foundational knowledge in the design, analysis, and improvement of complex systems. Students will learn how to apply quantitative methods to optimize processes, improve efficiency, and make data-driven decisions across various industries. This minor is suitable for students in engineering, business, computer science, and other technical fields who wish to broaden their skill set in systems thinking and operational excellence.
Program name: Minor in Industrial and Systems Engineering

description: The Information Technology (IT) Minor focuses on the application, design, installation, and management of information technology resources for organizations. Topics include: database systems, networking, web development, information security, and project management. The IT Minor allows students outside of the Information Technology major to apply IT skills to their major. Students are provided with hands-on experience by completing projects which use current information technologies. The Minor provides a solid foundation for those students wishing to pursue careers in IT as well as preparing students for graduate studies in IT related fields. IT Minor coursework complements a wide range of academic majors at UNC Charlotte.

The Bachelor of Science in International Business provides an excellent opportunity to develop the business knowledge and cross-cultural expertise needed to succeed in an increasingly globalized world. The program also integrates significant opportunities for international experience through study abroad, internships, and language immersion, fostering a deeper understanding of diverse cultures and business practices. Graduates are well-prepared to work in various international roles, including import/export, international marketing, global supply chain management, and foreign direct investment. The curriculum covers core business functions such as finance, marketing, and management, alongside specialized international business topics, including international trade, global economic environments, and cross-cultural communication.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in International Business

description: The minor in International Studies is an interdisciplinary minor designed for students interested in a structured program of study in international topics outside their major field of study. International Studies minors develop a broader and deeper understanding of the processes of globalization; the cultural, economic, social, and political diversity of the world's peoples; and the forces driving international cooperation and conflict.

The minor in Japanese is designed to give students exposure to the Japanese language and culture. Students can complete the minor with 18 credit hours of Japanese language beyond JAPN 1202 or 15 credit hours beyond JAPN 2202. The minor is offered by the Department of Languages and Culture Studies. For more information, please contact the department.

The interdisciplinary Minor in Jewish Studies offers students the opportunity to explore the rich history, culture, religion, and politics of the Jewish people. This minor provides a humanistic approach to studying Jewish civilization from ancient times to the present. The program prepares students for a variety of careers in fields such as law, education, journalism, social work, public service, and the arts, or for further graduate study in related areas. A minor in Jewish Studies complements many majors offered at UNC Charlotte, including political science, history, religious studies, international studies, English, philosophy, and sociology.

If you have an interest in a career in journalism or simply want to improve your writing and communication skills, then the Journalism minor might be for you. The minor provides students with a foundational understanding of key journalistic principles and practices including newsgathering, writing, and editing across various media platforms. Students develop a strong ethical framework, critical thinking abilities, and practical skills necessary for effective communication in a rapidly evolving media landscape. The curriculum emphasizes hands-on experience, preparing students for diverse roles in traditional and digital journalism, public relations, content creation, and related fields.

The minor in K-12 and Foreign Language Education provides students with the opportunity to gain a deeper understanding of the field of foreign language education for grades K-12. The minor is a useful addition for students majoring in a foreign language such as French, German or Spanish, as well as students majoring in other fields who wish to develop knowledge and skills in foreign language teaching. The minor provides a foundation in language acquisition, second language teaching methods, and curriculum development. It is designed to prepare students for careers in foreign language education, international education, and related fields. The minor may also be helpful for students considering graduate studies in foreign language education or related fields. Students will develop an understanding of current theories and practices in foreign language education, as well as the ability to apply these theories in practical settings. The minor requires 18 credit hours, including 9 hours of core courses and 9 hours of electives.
Program name: Minor in K-12 and Foreign Language Education

description: A Minor in Kinesiology provides students with a foundational understanding of the science of human movement and its application to various fields such as exercise science, sport, and health. Students will explore topics including exercise physiology, biomechanics, motor control, and health promotion, gaining insights into how physical activity impacts human performance, disease prevention, and overall well-being. This minor is suitable for students pursuing careers in healthcare, education, sports, and research, offering a valuable complement to a wide range of majors.

A minor in Landscape Architecture is a valuable asset for students with a wide array of majors including Architecture, Biology, Business, Civil Engineering, Computer Science, Earth Science, Environmental Studies, Geography, History, Liberal Studies, Mechanical Engineering, Political Science, Public Health, Sociology, Sustainable Technologies, Urban Studies, and others. The minor exposes students to key principles and practices in landscape architecture including cultural and natural systems, environmental design, site analysis, and graphical communication techniques. Students learn to critically evaluate landscapes, address environmental challenges, and propose design interventions that are ecologically sound, socially responsible, and aesthetically compelling. The Minor requires 18 credit hours, consisting of three core courses (9 credit hours) and three elective courses (9 credit hours) taken from a list of approved courses. The Minor is intended to provide foundational knowledge and skills in landscape architecture to students whose major is in another discipline.
Accreditation status: NOT accredited by the Landscape Architectural Accreditation Board (LAAB) of the American Society of Landscape Architects (ASLA).

description: The Latin American Studies minor provides an interdisciplinary approach to the study of Latin America and the Caribbean, including the United States as part of the Americas. Students learn about the region’s diverse cultures, histories, politics, and economies through courses in History, Political Science, Spanish, Geography, Anthropology, and other departments. The program emphasizes critical thinking, research skills, and cultural competency, preparing students for careers in fields such as international relations, education, business, journalism, and public service, as well as for graduate studies. The minor consists of 18 credit hours, including one core course and 15 elective credit hours. Students must complete a minimum of 9 credit hours at the 3000 level or above. All courses must be completed with a grade of C or better.

The minor in Legal Studies is a cross-disciplinary program designed to give undergraduates a broad understanding of the nature and function of law, legal institutions, and legal processes. The minor aims to provide students with critical skills in legal analysis, reasoning, and research; to introduce students to the various roles that lawyers play in society; and to provide students with an understanding of the relationship between law and other disciplines. The minor will provide students with a solid foundation for further study in law and related fields.

The Bachelor of Science in Management degree prepares students for leadership roles in a variety of organizations across all industries. This interdisciplinary program provides students with the fundamental business and management skills required to be successful in the modern business world. Through project-based learning and experiential opportunities, students learn how to manage complex projects, lead diverse teams, foster innovation, and make effective decisions.

Management Information Systems (MIS) combines the knowledge of business operations with the technical skills to design, develop, and manage information systems to improve efficiency and decision making within organizations. Students learn to analyze business problems, design appropriate technology solutions, implement and manage those solutions, and analyze data to support business decisions. The curriculum provides a strong foundation in both business and technology, preparing graduates for a variety of roles such as business analyst, systems analyst, IT consultant, database administrator, project manager, and data analyst.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Management Information Systems

description: The Management Information Systems minor provides students with the fundamental concepts and techniques of management information systems. The program consists of 12 credit hours focusing on topics such as database management, business intelligence, systems analysis and design, and enterprise resource planning. The minor is suitable for students in any major seeking to enhance their knowledge and skills in the field of information systems to complement their primary area of study.
